definitions: A nucleotide formed when ATP loses one phosphate group (ATP → ADP + Pi).
The lower-energy form of ATP after one phosphate bond has been broken.
A molecule that can be rephosphorylated to ATP to store usable cellular energy.
A product of ATP hydrolysis that helps signal cellular energy demand.
A nucleotide formed when ATP loses two phosphate groups (ATP → AMP + PPi in some reactions).
A low-energy adenine nucleotide that rises when cellular energy is stressed.
A molecule produced in the adenylate kinase reaction (2 ADP → ATP + AMP).
A cellular signal of low energy status that can help regulate metabolism.
An enzyme that catalyzes ATP breakdown into ADP + inorganic phosphate (Pi).
A protein that uses the energy released from ATP hydrolysis to do work (e.g., pumping ions, moving filaments).
An ATP-splitting enzyme; different ATPases perform different cellular tasks.
A catalyst that converts ATP’s chemical energy into mechanical, transport, or signaling work.
The primary energy currency of the cell.
A high-energy nucleotide whose phosphate bonds provide usable energy when hydrolyzed.
A molecule that stores and transfers energy to power cellular work (contraction, transport, synthesis).
The immediate energy source for many biological processes, regenerated continuously.
Reaction that regenerates ATP by combining two ADP molecules: 2 ADP → ATP + AMP.
A rapid ATP-buffering reaction that helps maintain ATP during high demand.
A pathway that produces ATP and AMP when ADP accumulates.
Enzymatic reaction (via adenylate kinase) that supports short-term energy balance.
Requiring oxygen for energy production.
Describing processes that use O₂ as part of ATP generation.
Energy metabolism supported by oxygen availability (oxidative).
Relating to sustained activities primarily fueled by oxidative pathways.
Glycolysis occurring when oxygen is available; pyruvate is formed and can enter aerobic pathways.
Breakdown of glucose to pyruvate with downstream oxidation supported by oxygen.
Glycolytic production of pyruvate that can be converted to acetyl-CoA and enter the Krebs cycle.
Carbohydrate breakdown where end-product pyruvate is handled oxidatively rather than largely to lactate.
Increased enzyme activity caused by an activator binding away from the active site.
Enzyme stimulation via binding at a regulatory (allosteric) site that changes enzyme shape/function.
A regulation method where a molecule boosts enzyme rate without occupying the substrate site.
Positive allosteric regulation that enhances catalytic activity.
Decreased enzyme activity caused by an inhibitor binding away from the active site.
Enzyme slowing via binding at a regulatory site that alters enzyme conformation.
Negative regulation where a molecule reduces enzyme function without competing at the active site.
Allosteric control that lowers pathway flux by reducing a key enzyme’s activity.
Synthesis of complex molecules from simpler ones; requires energy input.
Building processes that consume ATP to create larger structures (e.g., protein synthesis).
Constructive metabolism: assembling tissues or molecules from smaller units.
Energy-requiring pathways that create storage or structural compounds.
Occurring without the use of oxygen.
Describing energy production that does not rely on O₂ availability.
Relating to pathways that can generate ATP without oxygen (phosphagen, glycolysis).
Metabolism or activity performed in the absence of sufficient oxygen supply.
Glycolysis without sufficient oxygen; produces ATP and lactate from pyruvate.
Carbohydrate breakdown where pyruvate is largely converted to lactate to maintain glycolytic flux.
ATP production via glycolysis with lactate formation when oxidative processing can’t keep up.
High-rate glycolytic pathway supporting intense efforts, commonly associated with lactate accumulation.
Breakdown of fatty acids into acetyl-CoA units for aerobic metabolism.
A mitochondrial process that chops fatty acids into two-carbon fragments (acetyl-CoA).
Fat metabolism pathway generating acetyl-CoA and electron carriers for ATP production.
Oxidative fat breakdown feeding the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain.
Study of how energy flows and is transformed in biological systems.
The science of ATP production, utilization, and energy pathways in cells.
Examination of metabolic systems supplying energy for life and exercise.
Field focused on how organisms capture, store, and use energy.
Amino acids with branched side chains: leucine, isoleucine, and valine.
Three essential amino acids commonly linked to muscle metabolism (Leu, Ile, Val).
Branched-structure amino acids that can be oxidized by muscle and influence protein synthesis signaling.
Leucine, isoleucine, and valine—dietary amino acids with unique branching structure.
An ATP-driven pump that moves calcium back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum to promote relaxation.
Enzyme that uses ATP to resequester Ca²⁺ into the SR after contraction.
Calcium pump responsible for lowering cytosolic calcium so muscle can relax.
ATPase that restores SR calcium stores by active transport.
Breakdown of complex molecules into simpler ones, releasing energy.
Degradative metabolism that produces substrates and energy (ATP/electron carriers).
Processes that dismantle fuels (carbs, fats, proteins) to harvest usable energy.
Energy-yielding metabolic pathways that reduce large compounds to smaller units.
Training that mixes different energy system demands within a session or program.
Programming that combines aerobic, anaerobic, and/or phosphagen-focused work.
A plan that integrates multiple metabolic targets (e.g., intervals + steady-state).
Training approach blending energy-system stresses to develop broad conditioning.
Pathway where lactate from muscle is converted to glucose in the liver.
Recycling loop: lactate → liver gluconeogenesis → glucose returned to blood.
A lactate-to-glucose conversion process supporting blood glucose during/after exercise.
Metabolic shuttle that helps clear lactate by converting it back into glucose.
Enzyme that transfers a phosphate from phosphocreatine to ADP to rapidly regenerate ATP.
Catalyst of the PCr system: PCr + ADP → ATP + creatine.
Key enzyme enabling immediate ATP resynthesis during short, intense efforts.
Rapid energy-buffer enzyme that maintains ATP availability in muscle.
High-energy phosphate compound used to rapidly regenerate ATP.
Stored phosphate donor that buffers ATP during maximal/near-maximal efforts.
Immediate energy reserve in muscle that replenishes ATP via creatine kinase.
A quick ATP resynthesis substrate in the phosphagen system.
Electron-transfer proteins involved in the electron transport chain.
Heme-containing carriers that pass electrons between ETC complexes.
Proteins that facilitate electron flow during oxidative phosphorylation.
ETC components that help move electrons toward oxygen as the final acceptor.
Reduction or exhaustion of energy substrates within cells.
Drop in stored fuel availability (e.g., glycogen or PCr).
A state where key metabolic resources become significantly reduced.
Loss of substrate stores that can limit performance or recovery.
Series of mitochondrial complexes that transfer electrons and drive ATP production.
Electron-passing system that creates a proton gradient used to make ATP.
Oxidative pathway where NADH/FADH2 donate electrons to ultimately reduce oxygen to water.
Mitochondrial membrane complexes that power oxidative phosphorylation via chemiosmosis.
A chemical reaction that requires an input of energy.
Energy-consuming reaction; products have higher free energy than reactants.
Non-spontaneous reaction that must be driven (often by coupling to ATP).
Reaction that proceeds only when energy is supplied.
The capacity to do work.
Ability to produce change or perform work on a system.
In physiology, usable capacity to drive biological processes (often via ATP).
A property that can be transformed (chemical, mechanical, thermal) but not created or destroyed.
A substance used to produce energy, such as carbohydrate, fat, or protein.
Fuel source oxidized or broken down to support ATP resynthesis.
Metabolic input that can be converted into ATP through cellular pathways.
Nutrients that serve as raw materials for energy production.
Elevated oxygen uptake after exercise that helps restore resting conditions.
Post-exercise rise in VO₂ used for recovery processes (restoring PCr, clearing metabolites, temperature).
The extra oxygen consumed above resting level during recovery following exercise.
Recovery oxygen consumption reflecting the cost of returning the body to homeostasis.
A chemical reaction that releases energy.
Energy-yielding reaction; products have lower free energy than reactants.
Spontaneous reaction that can drive work or be coupled to endergonic processes.
Reaction that liberates usable energy (often captured in ATP/electron carriers).
High-rate glycolysis that rapidly produces ATP and lactate.
Glycolytic ATP production at high intensity with significant lactate formation.
Carbohydrate breakdown pathway emphasized during hard efforts when energy demand is high.
Rapid ATP resynthesis via glycolysis, commonly associated with higher lactate and H+ accumulation.
An electron carrier that donates electrons to the electron transport chain.
Reduced form of FAD produced during aerobic metabolism (e.g., Krebs cycle).
Electron shuttle that feeds electrons into the ETC at a different entry point than NADH.
A reduced coenzyme that transports high-energy electrons for oxidative ATP production.
Formation of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources.
Glucose synthesis from lactate, glycerol, or certain amino acids.
A metabolic pathway (notably in liver) that rebuilds glucose when carbs are limited.
Process that helps maintain blood glucose during fasting or prolonged exercise.
Breakdown of glycogen into glucose (or glucose-1-phosphate) for energy use.
Mobilization of stored carbohydrate from muscle or liver glycogen.
Process of splitting glycogen to supply substrate for glycolysis.
Conversion of glycogen stores into usable glucose units.
Metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose to produce ATP and pyruvate.
A series of reactions converting glucose into pyruvate with net ATP production.
Carbohydrate breakdown pathway occurring in the cytosol, producing ATP quickly.
Glucose-to-pyruvate energy pathway that can proceed with or without oxygen downstream.
Relating to glycolysis or the glycolytic energy system.
Describing metabolism that relies heavily on glucose breakdown for ATP.
Pertaining to the pathway producing ATP from carbohydrate via glycolysis.
Associated with glycolysis-driven energy production (often higher-intensity efforts).
Repeated high-intensity work bouts separated by recovery periods.
Training format alternating very hard efforts with rest or low-intensity intervals.
Interval method designed to stress anaerobic and/or aerobic systems via intense repeats.
Work-rest training using short-to-moderate bursts near maximal intensity.
Chemical breakdown of a compound using water.
Reaction where water splits a bond (e.g., ATP hydrolysis).
Process that cleaves molecules by adding water across a bond.
A common reaction type in metabolism, including ATP → ADP + Pi.
A free phosphate group released during ATP breakdown.
Phosphate ion (Pi) produced when ATP is hydrolyzed.
A product of ATP splitting that can influence muscle contraction and fatigue processes.
Released phosphate that participates in energy-transfer reactions.
Training alternating periods of work and recovery.
Method using repeated bouts with rest/active rest between efforts.
Programming that manipulates intensity and recovery to target specific adaptations.
A structured work-rest approach to develop fitness and performance.
Series of reactions that oxidize acetyl-CoA to produce electron carriers for ATP production.
Mitochondrial cycle that generates NADH/FADH2 and CO₂ from acetyl-CoA.
Central aerobic pathway feeding electrons to the ETC via NADH and FADH2.
Oxidative metabolic cycle that processes acetyl-CoA for energy harvest.
A product formed from pyruvate during high glycolytic flux.
The conjugate base produced when pyruvate is reduced to help regenerate NAD⁺.
A metabolite associated with intense exercise, produced during anaerobic glycolysis.
A transportable fuel/signaling molecule that can be shuttled and oxidized elsewhere.
Exercise intensity where lactate begins to accumulate rapidly in blood.
Point at which lactate production outpaces clearance, causing a sustained rise in blood lactate.
A threshold intensity used to estimate endurance performance and training zones.
The workload where lactate levels show a clear, non-linear increase.
Common term used to refer to lactate plus associated hydrogen ions during high-intensity metabolism.
Often-used label for the byproducts of rapid glycolysis (lactate and H⁺).
A historical/colloquial term; in physiology discussions it typically points to lactate-related acidity.
Term frequently used in training contexts to describe metabolite buildup during intense exercise.
Reaction rate and direction depend on concentrations of reactants and products.
Principle stating that substrate/product levels influence how a chemical reaction proceeds.
Concept that increasing reactants drives reactions forward; increasing products can drive reverse.
Rule describing how concentration changes shift equilibrium and reaction speed.
Shifting a reaction’s direction by changing substrate or product concentration.
Driving a reaction forward by increasing reactant availability or removing products.
Practical outcome of the law of mass action in metabolic pathways.
Concentration-driven push/pull that changes reaction flow.
Decrease in muscle or blood pH due to increased hydrogen ion concentration.
Acidic shift from elevated H⁺ associated with high-intensity metabolism.
Condition where buffering is challenged and pH drops during hard exercise.
Lowered pH state linked to intense work and high glycolytic activity.
Adaptations are specific to the metabolic demands imposed by training.
Training principle: energy-system changes reflect the intensity and duration patterns practiced.
Conditioning improvements depend on which substrates/pathways are repeatedly stressed.
Rule that metabolic adaptations mirror the work-rest and intensity profile of training.
Sum of all chemical reactions in the body.
All processes that build (anabolism) and break down (catabolism) molecules.
Total biochemical activity that maintains life and supports work.
Integrated network of reactions that produce energy and synthesize/repair tissues.
Cell organelles where aerobic ATP production occurs.
Site of oxidative metabolism: Krebs cycle and electron transport chain.
Organelles that use oxygen to produce large amounts of ATP.
Cellular “powerhouses” generating ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.
Another name for the adenylate kinase reaction: 2 ADP → ATP + AMP.
ATP-buffer reaction producing ATP and AMP when ADP accumulates.
Enzyme-mediated reaction that supports rapid ATP maintenance during intense efforts.
Short-term energy-balancing pathway: combines two ADP molecules to restore one ATP.
An enzyme on the myosin head that hydrolyzes ATP to power cross-bridge cycling.
ATP-splitting activity of myosin that drives muscle contraction mechanics.
Catalytic function enabling myosin to use ATP energy for force and movement.
Enzyme action that provides energy for the power stroke and detachment steps.
Reactions that readily reverse direction depending on substrate/product concentrations.
Steps that operate close to equilibrium and can run forward or backward easily.
Reversible reactions whose direction is strongly influenced by mass action.
Metabolic reactions not strongly rate-limited, shifting based on reactant/product levels.
An electron carrier that transports electrons to the electron transport chain.
Reduced coenzyme formed during glycolysis/Krebs that donates electrons for ATP production.
A key electron shuttle delivering high-energy electrons to the ETC.
Carrier molecule that links fuel oxidation to oxidative phosphorylation.
Exercise intensity where blood lactate reaches about 4 mmol/L.
A lactate threshold marker commonly defined by the 4 mmol/L criterion.
Work rate at which blood lactate hits ~4 mM during incremental testing.
Operational definition of a threshold point indicating significant lactate accumulation.
ATP production driven by electron transport and chemiosmosis in mitochondria.
Process using the proton gradient from the ETC to synthesize ATP.
Mitochondrial ATP generation coupled to oxygen use as the final electron acceptor.
ATP formation via ATP synthase powered by a membrane proton motive force.
Energy system that produces ATP using oxygen (aerobic metabolism).
Long-duration ATP supply relying on mitochondria and oxygen.
Aerobic energy pathway using carbs/fats (and sometimes protein) to make ATP.
System supporting sustained work via oxidative phosphorylation.
Older term roughly referring to postexercise oxygen consumption.
Historical concept describing elevated oxygen use after exercise (now commonly EPOC).
Legacy label for recovery oxygen requirement following intense activity.
Term often replaced in modern texts by EPOC.
Shortfall between oxygen required and oxygen actually consumed at exercise onset.
Initial lag in aerobic energy supply when starting exercise.
Gap between energy demand and oxidative contribution early in a bout.
Early-exercise period where anaerobic sources help cover energy needs until VO₂ rises.
Amount of oxygen consumed by the body.
Rate at which oxygen is used for aerobic metabolism (often expressed as VO₂).
Physiological measure reflecting aerobic energy turnover.
Oxygen consumption used to estimate intensity and aerobic capacity.
Energy system that rapidly resynthesizes ATP using phosphocreatine.
Immediate ATP supply system using stored ATP and PCr for short, intense efforts.
Fastest ATP regeneration pathway, dominant in very short-duration maximal work.
System relying on high-energy phosphates (ATP and PCr) rather than oxygen.
Stored high-energy phosphate used to regenerate ATP quickly.
Immediate phosphate reserve that donates a phosphate to ADP via creatine kinase.
High-energy compound that buffers ATP during maximal sprint/lift efforts.
Muscle energy store central to the phosphagen system.
Key rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis.
Major regulatory enzyme controlling glycolytic flux.
Enzyme that catalyzes a central step in glycolysis often used as a control point.
A primary “gatekeeper” enzyme determining glycolysis speed under many conditions.
Addition of a phosphate group to a molecule.
Attachment of phosphate that can change a molecule’s activity or energy state.
Process used in metabolism to activate substrates or store energy.
Common biochemical modification influencing signaling and metabolic pathways.
End product of glycolysis before conversion to lactate or entry into aerobic pathways.
Three-carbon molecule produced from glucose breakdown in glycolysis.
Glycolytic product that can be converted to acetyl-CoA for the Krebs cycle.
Key metabolic junction: can be reduced to lactate or oxidized aerobically.
Slowest step in a pathway that controls overall process rate.
Bottleneck reaction determining how fast a pathway can run.
Regulatory step often targeted by enzymes that are highly controlled.
The step whose kinetics largely set pathway flux.
Restoration of depleted energy substrates.
Refilling fuel stores after they’ve been reduced (e.g., glycogen or PCr).
Recovery process of replenishing metabolic resources after exercise.
Return of substrate levels toward baseline following depletion.
Lower-rate glycolysis with less lactate accumulation, often at lower intensities.
Glycolytic ATP production occurring at a slower pace with relatively more oxidative support.
Carbohydrate breakdown pathway operating at moderate rates with minimal lactate rise.
Glycolysis emphasizing pyruvate handling without rapid lactate buildup.
ATP-driven enzyme that maintains sodium and potassium gradients across membranes.
Membrane pump using ATP to move Na⁺ out and K⁺ into cells.
Ion-transport ATPase essential for resting membrane potential and excitability.
Active transport system preserving electrochemical gradients for nerve and muscle function.
ATP production by direct transfer of a phosphate group to ADP.
ATP formation that does not require oxygen or the electron transport chain.
Direct phosphorylation of ADP using energy from an intermediate (e.g., in glycolysis).
Non-ETC ATP synthesis occurring in cytosolic or mitochondrial pathway steps.
Body mass including water; sometimes referenced in body composition or scaling discussions.
Tissue mass measured with its water content included (not dehydrated mass).
A term used when discussing muscle mass as measured in typical physiological conditions.
Muscle mass concept that includes intracellular and extracellular water.
Relationship between exercise duration and recovery duration in intervals.
Interval design variable comparing work time to rest time (e.g., 1:2).
Programming ratio that shapes energy system stress and recovery demands.
A way to describe how long you work relative to how long you recover.
